mxCell.value: PhD Project Timeline - Urban Heat and Health in Johannesburg
1. Protocol Paper (Month 4): 'Leveraging data science and machine learning for urban climate adaptation in two major African cities: a HE2AT Center study protocol'
2. Vulnerability Paper (Month 9): 'Quantifying intra-urban socio-economic and environmental vulnerability to extreme heat events in Johannesburg, South Africa'
3. Explanatory ML Paper (Month 19): 'Uncovering Heat-Health Pathways in Johannesburg: An Explanatory Machine Learning Approach Using Harmonized Urban Cohort Data'
4. Predictive Modeling Paper (Month 33): 'Developing Stratified Heat-Health Early Warning Systems for Johannesburg: Integration of Vulnerability Mapping and Predictive Modeling'

Primary risks include data accessibility challenges, computational constraints, and model performance issues. Detailed timelines, activities, and risk mitigation strategies are provided in Appendix C.
Conceptual Framework: Urban Heat Vulnerability in Johannesburg
• Urban Heat Islands • Surface Temperature • Land Cover/Land Use • Vegetation Density • Building Density
• Age Demographics • Pre-existing Health Conditions • Comorbidities (HIV, TB) • Inflammatory Markers • Renal Function
• Air Conditioning Access • Housing Quality • Public Cooling Access • Green Space Proximity • Healthcare Access
• Unequal access to protective infrastructure • Spatial patterns of heat vulnerability • Socio-economic exclusion patterns

• Geographically Weighted Principal Component Analysis (GW-PCA) • Causal Machine Learning (PC Algorithm, XGBoost with SHAP) • LASSO Regression for Predictive Modeling • Spatio-temporal modeling with DLNM
• Heat-related mortality • Cardiovascular events • Renal dysfunction • Respiratory exacerbations
• Early warning systems • Urban greening strategies • Housing policy interventions • Healthcare resource allocation
• Accelerating warming trends • Increased extreme heat events • Urban heat island intensification • IPCC AR6 regional projections

• Access to protective infrastructure • Legacy of socio-spatial patterns

• Differential health impacts • Vulnerable population identification
